ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: And no one is comparable to Him.'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: There is no one comparable to Him."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: and none is comparable to Him.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: There is no one equal to Him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: “And there is none equal to Him.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And there is none comparable to Him."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: and equal to Him is not any one.'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And there is none comparable unto Him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and there is nothing like Him."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And there hath never been co-equal with Him anyone.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: And there is none like unto Him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And there is none co-equal or comparable unto Him."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: and there is none equal to Him'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And there is nothing comparable to Him.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Nor is there to Him any equivalent."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [112:4] Nor is there anyone equal to Him’, neither match nor comparison (lahu, ‘to Him’, is semantically connected to kufuwan, ‘equal’, but precedes it because it is the object of the intended negation; ahadun, ‘anyone’, which is the subject of yakun, ‘is there’, has been placed after the predicate of the latter [kufuwan, ‘equal’] in order to retain the harmony of the end-rhyme [of the verses]). Meccan or Medinese, consisting of 5 verses. This sūra and the next one were revealed when Labīd the Jew placed a spell on the Prophet (s) using a string with eleven knots. God informed him of this and of its place, and so it was brought before the Prophet (s) and he was commanded to ‘seek refuge [in God]’ by means of these two sūras; and so each time he recited a verse from them, a knot would become undone and he would sense an alleviation, until in the end all the knots had been undone and he stood up invigorated, as if he had previously been hobbled to the ground.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (And there is none comparable unto Him) He says: He does not have an opposite, peer, or equal nor anyone who may resemble or begin to resemble Him; and it is also said this means: He does not have any co-equal who would compete with Him about dominion and sovereignty'. And of the surah in which Daybreak is mentioned, which is all Meccan-and it is also said it is Medinan-and consists of 5 verses, 23 words and 69 letters: Surah 113: Daybreak (al-Falaq) And of the surah in which Daybreak is mentioned, which is all Meccan — and it is also said it is Medinan — and consists of 5 verses, 23 words and 69 letters:
